name: Long Island
description: About 75 miles east of New York City, Long Island Wine Country benefits from a maritime climate created by the Atlantic Ocean, Long Island Sound, and Great Peconic  Bay between the North Fork and South Fork, known as The Hamptons.

name: New York City
description: One of the world's top cities for great food and wine, New York City now has many leading restaurants which feature "local" New York wines from various regions, often paired with local foods.

name: Hudson River Valley/Catskills
description: One of America's oldest wine producers with wineries on both sides of the majestic waterway, the Hudson River Region benefits from warm maritime air from the Atlantic Ocean funneled through the steep palisades.

name: North Country
description: North Country, which includes the Adirondacks, Lake Champlain and Thousand Islands, is the newest wine region in New York. Because of their unique climate  they specialize in cold hardy grapes which are becoming more popular.

name: Finger Lakes
description: The breathtakingly beautiful Finger Lakes region has 11 lakes carved out by Ice Age glaciers, though "wine country" is concentrated around four in the center of the region: Cayuga, Seneca, Keuka, and Canandaigua.

name: Lake Erie
description: The largest grape growing region outside of California parallels the south shore of Lake Erie, benefiting from its temperature-moderating effects for over 20,000 acres of grapes for juice and wine.

name: Niagara
description: Just east of iconic Niagara Falls separating the United States from Canada, the Greater Niagara wine region includes two parallel wine trails running east to west – Lake, and Ridge—as well as an official American Viticultural Area known as the Niagara Escarpment with special grape growing characteristics.

name: Other Western Counties
description: New York State now has wineries in 59 of its 62 counties, including many places never before considered to be "wine country" but now are.

name: Lake Ontario
description: The easternmost of the Great Lakes, Lake Ontario’s expansive waters moderate the temperatures allyear, allowing the production of apples, grapes and wine.

name: Central New York
description: Though not located in any traditionally defined wine region, Central New York has experienced significant growth in the number of wineries.
